steps.title: Use an all-purpose dye for dyeing your running shoes.
steps.content: Use an all-purpose dye for dyeing your running shoes. Most shoe materials can be dyed using an all-purpose dye. You can purchase all-purpose dye at a craft store or an online retailer.

steps.title: Test dye a small patch of your running shoes beforehand.
steps.content: Test dye a small patch of your running shoes beforehand. Make sure your shoes are suitable for the dyeing process by testing a small patch before dyeing the entire shoe. If the test dye sets then you should be able to successfully dye your running shoes. If it doesn't you might want to try a different dye. Keep in mind that many shoes have been treated with a surface finish during the manufacturing process making it difficult for the shoe to absorb a new dye. [1] X Research source If your test dye doesn’t set it might have a surface finish on it.

steps.title: Set up a clean workspace.
steps.content: Set up a clean workspace. Find a clear area where you can set up your materials. Cover this area with a plastic drop cloth or several layers of newspaper to avoid any leakages. Wear rubber gloves when handling the dye to avoid staining your hands and be sure to wear clothes that you can get dirty in. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the shoelaces from your shoes.
steps.content: Remove the shoelaces from your shoes. Be sure to remove your shoelaces if you don’t want them to be dyed along with your shoes. [3] X Research source Simply unlace both laces and set them aside until the dyeing process is finished. If you decide that you want your shoelaces to be dyed remove them from your shoes and add them in the dye mixture on their own to ensure an even dye.

steps.title: Take out your shoe insoles.
steps.content: Take out your shoe insoles. If it's possible, remove the insoles of your shoes to avoid dyeing them. Reach into your shoe, pull out the insole and set it aside. If you have removable insoles its best to exclude them from the dying process as they could become misshapen.

steps.title: Protect the outer soles of your shoes.
steps.content: Protect the outer soles of your shoes. If you don’t want the soles of your shoes to be dyed, cover them with rubber cement or a layer of petroleum jelly. These can be washed or peeled off after the dyeing process. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Scrub away any smudges or stains from the shoes.
steps.content: Scrub away any smudges or stains from the shoes. You want to make sure they are clean so that the dye spreads evenly. Use warm water with soap and a sponge to clear away all marks. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Fill the bucket or sink with about 12 quarts of hot water.
steps.content: Fill the bucket or sink with about 12 quarts of hot water. This should be enough water to completely submerge your running shoes. Heat the water beforehand to approximately 140 °F (60 °C) over the stove in a large cooking pot. Fill the sink or bucket with the hot water. Pour the water from the pot very carefully into the sink/bucket as not to splash yourself with hot water.

steps.title: Add the dye to the water.
steps.content: Add the dye to the water. Following the instructions on the dye packet, pour the dye into the hot water in the sink/bucket. Stir the dye into the water until it looks dissolved. Use an old mixing spoon to stir in the dye. The dye can stain the vessel you are using during the dyeing process so be sure to use a bucket or sink that can get dirty. Also be advised that your mixing spoon will be dyed in the process so be sure to use a mixing spoon that you don’t mind getting dye on.

steps.title: Put a tablespoon of dish detergent into the dye mixture.
steps.content: Put a tablespoon of dish detergent into the dye mixture. Adding a small amount of dish detergent will help the dye spread evenly. Stir the detergent into the mixture slowly until it is well-mixed. You can use any kind of dish detergent you use to wash dishes with. Be sure to avoid making bubbles from stirring the detergent too fast.

steps.title: Wet your shoes in warm water.
steps.content: Wet your shoes in warm water. Make sure your shoes are already wet before putting them into the dye mixture. Briefly run your shoes under warm tap water to wet them. This will allow the dye to seep into your shoes more easily. [6] X Research source Your shoes don’t need to be completely saturated with water at this point. You just want to make sure they are a little damp. Be sure to wet the entire shoe, even the inside, so that the dye fully absorbs into the shoe.

steps.title: Lower your shoes into the dye bath carefully.
steps.content: Lower your shoes into the dye bath carefully. Using your gloved hands, put the shoes into the dye one at a time. Avoid dropping the shoes into the dyebath hastily as this could cause the dye to splash. The temperature of the dyebath is hot! Be cautious when lowering your shoes into the mixture as to not burn yourself.

steps.title: Soak your shoes for about 1 hour.
steps.content: Soak your shoes for about 1 hour. Let the shoes sit in the dye mixture for at least an hour to enable them to absorb the dye. Leave the shoes in the dye for as long as you want based on the level of color saturation you desire. For example, if you are dyeing your shoes blue and you want them to have a rich, dark blue appearance you can leave them in the dyebath for a longer amount of time. If you wish to dye your shoes a lighter shade of blue leave them in the dyebath for a shorter amount of time. Remember that you can always check the color saturation of your shoes during the dyeing process by carefully pulling them out and holding them over the dyebath to judge. If you decide you want your shoes to be darker, slip them back into the dyebath.

steps.title: Rinse your shoes with cool water.
steps.content: Rinse your shoes with cool water. After removing your shoes from the dye run them under cool tap water until the water begins to run clear. You want to make sure that any leftover dye is washed out from your shoes. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Pat the wet shoes with paper towels.
steps.content: Pat the wet shoes with paper towels. There shouldn’t be any traces of dye on the paper towel. Your shoes will still be a bit damp but they shouldn’t be dripping wet. Avoid leaving your shoes dripping wet as any leftover dye can stain.

steps.title: Clean up the soles of the shoes.
steps.content: Clean up the soles of the shoes. Take off the liquid cement or petroleum jelly from the soles. If you used liquid cement you should be able to peel it off of the soles. If you used petroleum jelly, take a wet paper towel and some soap and scrub off the leftover petroleum jelly contents.

steps.title: Give your shoes a good wash.
steps.content: Give your shoes a good wash. Finish the process by washing the shoes with warm water and soap or put them in the washing machine with a mild detergent. Washing your shoes ensures that the dye fully sets into the fabric.

steps.title: Leave your shoes to dry.
steps.content: Leave your shoes to dry. You can allow your shoes to air dry or you can put them in the dryer. Keep in mind that drying your shoes in the dryer can cause them to shrink. If you dyed your shoelaces leave them out to air dry. Allow your shoes to dry completely before wearing them. If you have a hairdryer handy you can use it to dry the insides of your shoes or any other hard to dry places.
